awd_titl_txt: NRI: FND: Robotic Human Enhancement Enabled through Wearable Hip Exoskeletons Capable of Community Ambulation
awd_abstract_narration:
The increased metabolic and biomechanical demands of ambulation limit community mobility in persons with lower limb disability due to neurological damage or advanced age. Robotic exoskeletons have the potential to assist these individuals to increase community mobility to improve quality of life. Current technology does not support dynamic movements, such as transitioning between different gaits and supporting a wide variety of walking speeds. This project proposes to meet this challenge by exploring an innovative myoelectric controller that brings together information across multiple muscles to assist the exoskeleton in a range of tasks for mobility. Of interest is how to extract information about the human user's intent, such as what speed the user wants to walk at or if they want to take a step up a stair. Recognizing intent will allow the device to give appropriate assistance over a wide range of activities. For this research project, the investigators will use a new type of robotic hip exoskeleton to augment the human hip during tasks such as walking at different speed, ramps and stairs. This project seeks to advance the state of the science in man-machine exoskeleton interfaces through new types of control techniques. This will help the team's long-term research goal of creating robotic assistive devices that benefit individuals with serious lower limb disabilities by improving mobility and, thus, overall independence. This NSF project will also include a significant outreach to the local Atlanta community. Local project partners will bring underserved minority students in the Atlanta area to Georgia Tech to participate in this educational program. These high school students will interact with the human assistive robotics in the lab and design, build, and program their own assistive robots through hands on education. This project will facilitate the training of an interdisciplinary group of students including graduate and undergraduate biomedical, electrical, and mechanical engineers, GT graduate students training to be clinical practitioners in prosthetics and orthotics, and physical therapists in training in Emory's DPT program. This interdisciplinary group of students will work together to fully integrate all aspects of the project and facilitate learning.

This research project will advance the knowledge of myoelectric (EMG) control for enabling humans to have dynamic movement assistance using lower limb robotic exoskeletons. Existing technologies of exoskeleton systems have limited high-level understanding of user intent, thus precluding adaptation to a proper range of daily tasks of living. Sensing modalities used in such systems do not provide sufficient information regarding key physiological parameters such as muscle activity. Conventional control algorithms relate a single modality of sensors to exoskeleton assistance and are thus incapable of fusing broader sets of varying sensor information. These technological gaps have impeded the translation of such systems beyond lab settings to clinical use where they can impact important health needs such as assistive rehabilitation. This proposal will address these gaps in assistive robotic technology by pursuing research organized in three key objectives: Objective 1) Determine the most effective strategy of providing exoskeleton hip assistance for reducing metabolic cost using a novel myoelectric controller. Objective 2) Compare the metabolic and biomechanical effects of a novel controller driven by myoelectric inputs vs a standard controller driven by kinematic inputs. Objective 3) Determine the contributions of high-level intent recognition using myoelectric information to improve control of a powered hip exoskeleton over simulated community terrain. Relatively simple mobility tasks like standing from a seated position or walking represent the primary outcome measures that determine independence in rehabilitation. Thus, the wearable exoskeleton system described in this grant proposal has the potential to make a measurable impact on enhancing the functional performance capabilities of individuals with lower limb deficits by increasing their quality of life, independence and well-being.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Robotic lower-limb exoskeletons have progressively emerged as a pivotal technology, with the potential to restore and augment human motor function and mobility. While these exoskeletons have achieved substantial success in enhancing human mobility by either offloading or supplementing the mechanical work executed by the user's musculature, a pertinent question surfaces: what is inhibiting this technology from being actualized in real-world scenarios? A critical limitation has been identified in the exoskeleton controller which was the focus of a series of studies conducted under this award.

In the earlier years of this 5-year effort, our team focused on gait phase estimation using robotic hip exoskeletons. We demonstrated in a series of papers that using machine learning on a carefully crafted dataset of our own making, that we could achieve subject-independent gait phase estimation that was capable of generalizing across a wide range of walking speeds as well as a wide range of locomotion modes such as level walking, ramp ascent/descent walking and stair locomotion. These contributions and build-up of our gait phase estimator were published in a series of journal papers. Additionally, we combined our gait phase estimator with a locomotion mode classifier which allowed for switching of torque profiles across modes to enable seamless control across walking, ramps and stairs. Our last contribution in this area was the development of an adaptive AI pipeline which enabled self-adaptation of gait phase estimation over time to learn the unique walking style of each individual which increased the accuracy substantially.

While the above contributions helped us make good progress towards real-world control, it was still very constraining in terms of the number of modes we could deliver, but more importantly, the torque profiles were static and did not adapt to the user. This limits overall performance gains and is not optimal. Our early ideas of improving control were to use EMG (myoelectric signaling) to improve capability. However, standard proportional myoelectric control for hip exoskeletons was deemed infeasible because of the lack of good hip flexion sensing with surface electrodes. Instead, we made a machine learning model that converted both mechanical sensors and EMG to biological torque (as measured through inverse dynamics). We used biological torque from the machine learning model to drive the exoskeleton control, which was far more adaptable to stride-to-stride variability, user variability and terrain/environment variability than our previous control style. However, in one of our first papers, we surprisingly found that EMG provided little added benefit in estimating human biological joint torque beyond the simple mechanical sensors (IMUs and encoders) inherent to our hip exoskeleton devices. This led to a breakthrough in control in that we could train and run fully user-independent biological joint estimation (since we did not need EMG) using device sensors alone. Another break-through occurred once we had sufficient data (~1 million examples) to use deep learning pipelines, we found that mode classification was no longer necessary to enable joint moment estimation across level-walking, ramps and stairs (e.g. we can estimate human joint moments in a task agnostic fashion) which enables user-independent and task-independent control of exoskeletons. This is a substantial improvement over current state-of-the-art exoskeleton controllers and represents a significant step towards real-world deployment and mobility enhancement with exoskeleton technology.

This award led to a total of 17 peer-reviewed and published journal publications and separately 17 peer-reviewed conference abstracts/papers. Journal publications were published in IEEE TRO, IEEE TNSRE, IEEE TBME, IEEE TMRB, JNER, IEEE RA-L, Journal of Biomechanics, and Annals of Biomedical Engineering. Conference publications were presented at ICORR, ICRA, BioRob, EMBC, ISMR, and ASB. There was also one patent filed (currently pending) on the exoskeleton controllers developed from this work.

This grant provided training for a total of 20 graduate students who worked on the project for at least some portion of their training at Georgia Tech which was a combination of PhD students, MS students, and MSPO students. Additionally, 41 undergraduate students worked on this project as part of their training for at least 1 semester. We ran a VIP (Vertically Integrated Projects) team as part of this project which trained 6-8 undergrads each semester in robotics which helped formalize the research through a highly structured program. Our team also established a summer camp in robotics program for high school students which was ran twice (cancelled due to COVID in the middle of the project) and was extremely successful. We also ran demos/showcases for National Robotics Week and Biomechanics Day each year (two major outreach events) each of which had many student groups with dozens of participants come to campus and learn about robotics research associated with this project.
